Articles.Content:
So I've created a new save, and currently revving up my program gradually from simple things to massive ones. But I've decided to prematurely take it a few steps further by developing a lightweight spacecraft that is capable of both escaping the solar system and grazing the sun's surface.

Behold, the Ion Maiden.

9 ion engines. 12 batteries. 16 cans of xenon gas. 48 RTGs.

I've used RTGs to prevent lagging my system, at the expense of lower constant but electricity yield no matter how far from the sun (to the point that I can't feel them working when the ion engines are at full thrust).

All of the images here are from its dry run. Its boosters alone (not using ion engines yet) are able to push it to an escape trajectory out of the solar system without refuelling in orbit - enough dv to push me in a very low solar periapsis.

Alright, just finished tinkering around, got the MK.2 ready to be launched anytime after few more tweaks. Removed the antennae and some RTGS as planned, and hooked up some i-beams and giant solar panels. I've conducted some tests and found out that it can now offset the power consumption of the ion engines at full throttle, so I'm considering to have some batteries removed to reduce part count further. I've only got a slight framerate drop with solar panels and engines running, not like what am I expecting.

Updated the launch vehicle also, docking ports for refuelling and 12 more cans of xenon gas attached near the solar panels for extra mileage.
